title: Lottery conman who stole £2,500,000 violently raped pregnant teenager
text:
Edward Putman, 54, has been named a ‘monster’ and ‘a dangerous, violent abuser’ by his victim (Picture: PA)

A lottery fraudster who fleeced Camelot out of millions violently raped a woman when she was 17 and pregnant.

Edward Putman, 54, has been named a ‘monster’ by his victim after he was jailed for nine years for using a fake lottery ticket to cash in an unclaimed £2.5 million jackpot.

His scheme – which became Britain’s biggest lottery fraud – was only revealed when his co-conspirator, who worked in the securities department at the lottery operator, confessed to a friend before killing himself.

Details of his rape conviction were withheld at his trial but can now be published after a jury took five hours to find him guilty yesterday.

In 1991, at the age of 25, the conman launched a horrific attack on the teenager, who was four months pregnant and had just left a children’s home after four years in care.

Advertisement

The victim, now 45, has said her attacker is a ‘dangerous, violent abuser’ who belongs in jail.

She told The Mirror: ‘I’m happy with the result. He is now where he belongs.

Putman was jailed for nine years for using a fake lottery ticket to cash in an unclaimed £2.5 million jackpot (Picture: PA)

‘He could be entertaining, he was funny, he made everyone laugh. Everyone thought he was the life and soul.

‘But he was a monster. For the sake of everybody, not just me, it is good that he is going down for a very long time.

‘I will be celebrating when he is behind bars. What he has done has had an impact on women and children.

‘He has stolen, he is a dangerous, violent abuser.’

‘I always knew what he was capable of… but nobody else did. Until now.’

She added: ‘He knew I was expecting when he attacked me. He said every time I screamed he would punch me again.

‘It happened about 20 more times. I really thought my head was going to cave in.’

The fake National Lottery ticket used by the conman (Picture: PA)

The builder, of Kings Langley in Hertfordshire, was sentenced to seven years for the rape and ordered to pay his victim £50,000 in compensation.

Yesterday, he was found guilty of fraud by false representation by jurors at St Albans Crown Court after he conspired with friend Giles Knibbs to swindle the lottery system.

The pair submitted a counterfeit slip to land the unclaimed £2.5 million in 2009.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The fraud came to light after Mr Knibbs took his own life in October 2015 after fearing he would go down for ’10 to 15 years for blackmail’, the trial heard.

The co-conspirators had fought over how the money was divided, with Mr Knibbs breaking Putman’s wing mirrors and stealing his phone during a heated argument in June 2015.

While he was passing the conman’s sentence, Judge Philip Grey said the ‘sophisticated, carefully planned, and diligently operated fraud’ struck at the heart of the integrity of the National Lottery.

He said: ‘You would have got away with this but quite plainly you were greedy.

Putman (right) arrives at St Albans Magistrates’ Court for his trial (Picture: PA)

‘Whatever the exact monetary split you and Mr Knibbs had agreed, you did not pay him what split he felt he was owed. The two of you fell out spectacularly.

‘This crime struck at the integrity of the National Lottery. You have also undermined the public’s trust in the lottery itself.’

The judge added that the fact Camelot had been ‘hoodwinked in this way will of course be damaging to its reputation’.

The genuine winning ticket, which was bought in Worcester, has never been found.

A Camelot spokesman said the case was a ‘unique, one-off incident over a decade ago’.

He said: ‘There were some weaknesses in some of the specific controls relevant to this incident at the time and we’re very sorry for that.

‘We’ve strengthened our processes significantly since then and are completely confident that an incident of this nature could not happen today.’

description: Lottery fraudster Edward Putman, who conned Camelot out of £2.5 million, violently raped a woman when she was 17 years old and pregnant.
